narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: course structure and content seemed to be determined primarily by the instructor's interests rather than a set of skills, topics, concepts that make up a foundation of knowledge in local land use planning.

this class was just not that good. i want to give kooris some latitude, considering this was his first time teaching. but really, the class sessions just felt like a waste of time. we spent far too long discussing the arbitrary issues related to news stories each and every class member brought in. instead of feeling like rich learning time, this functioned mostly as a stretch of intermittent attention for the whole class, as if kooris was just trying to get through the 3 hours of class. his lectures were rushed, self-referential, largely a rundown of his opinions on whatever topic was being discussed that day. there was little sense of continuity, of accumulation of material, or that any of our readings were much related to what was discussed. this class needs a serious overhaul, because it is SO important that FES offers it. unfortunately, it suffers from the same lack of teaching standards that many other courses here suffer from.

I do not believe the instructor prepared for class. In the event that he had prepared lecture slides, and allowed himself time to present them, which was not always the case, he frequently could not answer questions related to the content of the slides.Course teachings involved no conceptual framework, no tools, no theory, no methods, and very little content beyond the instructor's personal experience in the field, which was not only limited by his experience itself (having a relatively short career as he does), but also confined by the single geographic region of metropolitan New York (where he has spent his professional life). The myopic focus on New York was one area where students had provided input and requested a broadening of regional and international focus, but requests did not influence subsequent lessons. Class mostly consisted of the instructor sharing his opinion on matters, sometimes related to regional and local planning, and sometimes not related to the subject matter at all -- and often his opinions were misinformed.He had a casual attitude about managing class time. Often class would not start for ~15-30 minutes, break for ~15-30 minutes in the middle, and run over for ~15-30 minutes. It often felt like he was happy to waste time casually chatting about current events, rather than keeping to a lesson schedule or meeting goals of material to be covered. Again, the take-away after every class was that he had not prepared for it, had no objectives for the class in terms of a knowledge trajectory.In sum, I do not think this instructor is of FES or Yale caliber. I do not think he put time into the job, I do not think teaching interests him, I do not think he has a proclivity for it, and I do not think he had any meaningful objectives for the semester.I strongly recommend that FES not hire David Kooris again in a direct teaching position. His contribution might better fit as a guest lecturer.

There was minimal material or curriculum prepared for the class. David is extremely knowledgeable about regional planning issues, but I don't think the class was able to take advantage of this because the class discussions were so haphazard.

13. This was my first land use and planning course and was therefore extremely valuable. To be exposed to these concepts by an experienced practitioner was also an added value. My only suggestion is to add a little more theory and content in place of some of the discussions, and also to move those discussions to the latter half of the course to give more time for questions on the technical content. Also, a more technical assignment or two that would be comparable to a planning curriculum might also aid learning.

I thought that this class has promise but needs some adjustments.Namely, the news-sharing component of each class was a waste of time. This just doesn't need to happen. I understand there is some value in this exercise as a discussion-generating one, but it ended up just turning into students playing on laptops while the professor opined on each article without asking students to think about or comment on their peers' articles. Either make this exercise mean something by generating actual discussion as a result, or just eliminate it entirely. Students can read newspapers and do book reports on their on time--not in class.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The field trip to Stamford was incredibly helpful in understanding the power and the weaknesses of planning.
field trip and a few lectures were great. i appreciated that we had lots of time for discussion but see next question.
David Kooris is knowledgable, articulate and inspiring.
the group of students who were in it. this class was full of bright, imaginative, energetic people. that was squandered. most of class was us sitting there while the instructor talked at us.
David's passion, the field trip, the final paper

When we got more into the climate section, the sustainable communities section, and land use solutions and grants currently being used to create smart growth -- this was the more interesting and best part of the course.

I enjoyed the field trip, but think it could have been more educational had there been models and dynamics of development first studied, then illustrated directly through the sites observed. No attention given to environmental justice issues despite the displacement of an entire low income neighborhood for the featured development project.
learning about the perspective of a practitioner

The field trip was very useful to highlight the techniques the professor identified for healthy cities. It would have been more helpful to have one or two more, particularly in New Haven since the class was 3 hours on a Thursday night, a little more interaction would have been helpful.Professor Kooris definitely has extensive experience in the urban planning field and his anecdotes and experiences were very interesting learning experiences.
Professor Kooris' own experiences and his interest in student's own articles and opinions was remarkable.
The range of topics and the technical details were fantastic, as was the application of them in the walking tour of Stamford.

The professor truly had some amazing insight into the planned history of NYC and parts of CT. Unfortunately, this information was just thrown at students with little opportunity or prompts for feedback or critical thought.The professor's expertise is appreciated and valued as a strength of the course--but there was too much top-down pontificating.The readings were generally good, if a little redundant.The field trip was excellent.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Overall course structure was lacking. Lack of reading assignments meant very little individual learning outside of class. Last minute changes to the syllabus meant I was never sure what subject matter we would be covering that day. Spent far too much class time discussing trending articles, and not enough on organized lecture. The course would have benefited from additional assignments or guided class discussion that incorporated readings.

we spent too much time reviewing articles we'd each read. also room layout was not conducive to really engaged discussion and readings were not really incorporated into discussion so i doubt many people read them

I would have liked more organized lectures, especially toward the second half of the class. I think the article portion of the class is great but should be limited to no more than an hour of class. Also, the lectures on climate change were more focused on projects David has done himself. I would have really enjoyed a more general "this is land use planning for climate change" lecture.
time management.

the structure of how time is spent in class. Entirely too much time is spent on the articles. Though it is interesting to hear about what everyone else read we can do that on our own time. I wanted to tap into David's knowledge and experience at a greater depth.
The article sharing section was too long and should have been done with guided reading assigned to groups, maybe following a particular topic of interest throughout the semester.

All aspects. Its obviously a rich and relevant field of study, with vast implications for environmental footprints esp. in the developing world, but it's difficult to imagine this instructor is the one to teach it.
organization of lectures
Sticking to a curriculum in order to make the most out of our time there.

Some classes we spent the entire three hours going over current events articles. It would have been more helpful to have more interesting weekly topical readings that the class could have developed a more in depth discussion on. Our conversations about current events often just scratched the surface of important issues.
More structure! Maybe even more assignments during the semester?

The discussions were interesting but I felt like they took too much time away from the more technical and useful aspects of class in the lectures. I would suggest at minimum putting the lectures first and the discussions last.

Format, structure of class time, and materials presented.While this class screams "powerpoint!" it wasn't totally necessary and ended up being more of an afterthought by the time students were done with book reports/show-and-tell every week.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: No connection whatsoever.
yes

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Nikki added bits of information when she could. This was a minimally work- intensive TF, so N/A
his perspective was unique. he was engaging. his command of the topic showed throughout the course
A change in attitude towards students. She treated us like inferior beings and was only marginally interested in interacting with us.

Instructor: Nikki Johnson Springer  nikki was a non-entity. i have nothing to say about her because essentially she was kooris's administrative assistant. her input and involvement was pretty much the bare minimum.
Instructor: Nikki Johnson Springer  Willing to meet and talk over the final paper, but not knowledgeable about the topics I was interested in.

Instructor: Nikki Johnson Springer  I did not find she had anything substantive to contribute. Nor did she offer any organizational assistance, i.e., helping to keep class on schedule, helping to make arrangements for the field trip, (she failed the first time, and had to be prompted the second time, to reserve a van for the field trip), helping to post reading assignments in time for class to read them, helping to relay student feedback to the instructor to help class improve over the semester, etc. TA did not attend the field trip herself.

Instructor: Nikki Johnson Springer  While Nikki made some contributions to the course during discussions, there weren't many other occasions where we were able to learn from her experience. Perhaps using one of the course slots for a lecture in the future might be interesting.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Fits very well and I feel I have a general understanding of land use planning now.
It's extremely relevant to the area I want to work in.
I am really interested in urban land use issues, particularly interested in how to sustainably feed cities and food systems.
see below.
i want to develop skills in urban development

Regional planning is very important to the work I plan on doing with sustainability and cities. Learning from Professor Kooris' experience also gave me a better idea of the role of urban planners in where development goes in cities.
This normally wouldn't be part of my curriculum as an MF but it was a topic of much interest and concern to me, and I'm very glad I took it.
I have about 6+ years with land use planning, development, and protection in a rural context.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I am interested in land use planning as a profession.
because i want to learn about how city and regional planning occurs from a professional.
I had no background in Land Use Planning and wanted to learn some terminology.
To learn more about urban planning and the tools planners use with land use decisions.
I have interest in local and regional vehicles/models for GHG reduction and climate planning.
to develop urban development skills and understand the local government perspective
I am interested in planning and thought this course would enlighten me.
To gain perspective on the tools that planners use to pool resources at a regional level.
An interest in Urban Planning.

I'm very driven to see improvements in our urban and suburban form. Changing land use practices can make people happier and cities more sustainable. This was a valuable introduction to the topic and will help direct my future endeavors.
Familiarity based on previous academic and professional experience.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, I learned a lot. However, I think I could have learned even more, particularly on climate change mitigation and adaptation planning.
no.
yes.

No, I wish that I would have been given more resources for my topic of interest earlier on in the semester, and I felt that most of the zoning, grants, examples discussed in class focused too heavily on transportation.
No.
yes
No.
Yes.

Use of discussion time for more planning theory or technical discussions might have been useful. Also, a more technical and structured project might have been useful given that this was an introductory course. I did like the freedom we were given with the papers,however.

I can't really admit I learned much from this class other than interesting historical tidbits about NYC.There was simply too much recycled information from RPA that I can get online for free to peruse on my own schedule.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: This is a great course that is not too overwhelming. David is an inspiring character.
hold the teacher accountable for teaching a quality course.
Take it, but do the readings, or you won't get enough out of the class. It would really help to have some way of keeping students accountable for this reading.
Good introduction to planing at local and regional levels, if you have a particular interest, push for more resources early on in the semester.
I would strong advise other students not to take this course.
do all the readings and don'tmiss the school trip
Take advantage of the fact that you can write your final paper on anything remotely related and develop a research proposal or topic leveraging David's willingness to talk with you.

If you care about how cities can or could look, this gives you the practical details on how the urban and suburban form has been shaped historically and the processes that determine what gets done today.
Great for those with no prior planning/land use experience.
